awd_titl_txt: Developmental cascades: How motor development alters everyday learning experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent evidence suggests that acquiring new motor skills, such as learning to sit and learning to walk, may facilitate other aspects of infants’ development, such as spatial cognition and language learning. Despite studies linking motor development to cognitive and language development, a key source of support is missing: How does motor development change infants’ everyday learning experiences? Presumably, learning to sit and to walk creates new ways for infants to interact with other people and their surroundings, which facilitates other developmental advances. However, few studies have measured such changes outside of laboratory contexts. The central goals of this project are to innovate new methods for measuring infants’ daily learning experiences in the home, and to use those methods to create a unique, multi-modal datasets to share with the research community. Analyzing these data will reveal how the development of sitting and walking alters infants’ motor, visual, object, and language experiences, and whether and how those changing experiences facilitate later cognitive and language development. Characterizing the everyday learning experiences that support typical development, and how they are facilitated by motor development, may help in the design of interventions to improve developmental outcomes in infants with motor delays. 

Two studies will identify how infants’ everyday learning experiences change when learning to sit/walk, and whether such changes have a facilitative role on the development of spatial cognition and language. The first study will use a combination of recording techniques—video, wearable head cameras and eye trackers, inertial movement recording, and dense caregiver-report surveys—to assess learning experiences across the entire day in the home. The effect of motor skill acquisition on daily experiences will be determined by comparing infants of the same age who have versus have not acquired sitting/walking. The second study will longitudinally track how learning experiences change month-to-month over the transitions to sitting and walking. Follow-up tests of spatial cognition and language learning will determine which, if any, everyday learning experiences linked to motor skills facilitate later development. Grounding facilitative effects of motor skill in direct, longitudinal measurements of learning experiences in the home will provide stronger causal evidence compared with previous laboratory-based approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California

por.por_cntn:
In 2020, the University of California, Riverside (UCR) received a National Science Foundation award for a project entitled, “Developmental cascades: How motor development alters everyday learning experiences”. The goal of the 4-year project was to examine how changes in infants’ motor abilities—learning to sit and learning to walk—change infants’ everyday experiences—what they see, how they move, and what they explore in day-to-day life. Understanding what changes infants’ experiences is important because it shapes how they learn and develop.

The first major accomplishment of the project was to create new methods for measuring infants’ everyday experiences. Most studies of infants’ everyday behavior used video cameras to record what infants do, but video observations are time-consuming to collect and to score. This NSF project innovated two ways to measure infants’ experiences without relying on video. One used a text-message survey approach to ask parents multiple times throughout the day a set of questions about what their infants are doing (e.g., playing with objects, having a meal, etc.). Another method collected data from wearable motion sensors (similar to smartphone activity tracking) to measure infants’ movements (e.g., sitting, standing) throughout the entire day. These new methods allowed UCR researchers to collect more representative data about infants’ experiences and better understand how they change over development. Moreover, the UCR team published papers and publicly shared data and software to help other researchers adopt those techniques in their own work, helping to enhance research capacity in the United States. 

The second major accomplishment of the project was discovering how learning to independently walk changes infants’ motor and object experiences. Infants were studied using the survey method each month from 10 months, when most infants were not yet able to walk, to 13 months, when about half of the infants had learned to walk. When compared at the same age, infants who had learned to walk spent more time standing and less time restrained in seats compared to infants who had not yet learned to walk. Infants who could walk also accrued longer amounts of time each day holding objects while standing, which provides different opportunities to learn about objects by sharing them with caregivers. These data help researchers better understand how development in one area, such as learning to walk, might change how infants develop in another, such as how they learn the names for objects.

The third major accomplishment of the project was examining how infants’ everyday movement relates to their opportunities for learning language. Prior research suggests that infants who learn to sit earlier have larger vocabularies than infants who learn to sit later. UCR researchers investigated whether differences in the frequency of parents speaking to infants differs according to how much infants sat across the day by using the wearable sensor recording paired with a wearable audio recorder. Parents spoke more frequently during periods of the day where infants sat compared with periods where they were in other positions. This supports the idea that learning to sit facilitates vocabulary development through changes to parents’ speech.  

A final outcome of the project was to foster research opportunities and advance data science skills for students from backgrounds that are historically underrepresented in STEM fields. The grant funded three interns who completed intensive 10-week summer programs where interns designed their own research projects and learned to use statistical software to analyze data from the grant project. Funding from the grant also supported an undergraduate research conference in the Department of Psychology at UC Riverside, which is a federally-designated Hispanic Serving Institution where half of students are first-generation college attendees, to promote research participation in students from underrepresented backgrounds.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: John Franchak
